segments.text: Chapter one entitled Childhood and Before.
One of the birthrights of someone born in 1932 is the qualification as a depression baby.
On April 26, 1932, Margie Margaret Pressman, my mother, had her third boy.
Her father, Will Presnell, was a merchant, farmer, and postmaster.
The home that we lived in was next door to a country store that was more or less a company store for the farmers that lived on the land of my grandfather as sharecroppers.

At one time there were over 20 families that lived on the farm, farming cotton and corn on relatively small acreage since it was all done with horses and mules and was prior to there being any tractor power.
The sharecroppers farmed their crops
on what they called a third and fourth basis, or on the halves.
If you owned your own equipment and owned your own mules, then you farmed the land as a sharecropper and gave the landlord one third of the corn and one fourth of the cotton.
If the landlord had to furnish these implements of the husbandry, then the sharecropper received half of the corn and half of the cotton.
Most all of the land was farmed and was either in cotton or corn, and very little of it was in cattle.
Not a great deal is remembered about my childhood days, but I do recall seeing my father very angry at one time.
In fact, probably the only time that I can recall, with the exception of one other time
through the radio that we were listening to.
As I say, that was during the New Deal days when I was a child and there were federal programs to try to get the country back on its feet.
There was little money and what little there was was furnished by federal programs and one of the programs
where my father was trying to help out the sharecroppers.
He advanced them some funds based on the fact that they would get some federal funds.
And when the money came in, he took the money.
The federal bureaucrats considered this wrong and threatened to take some action.
And he was very upset with
sharecroppers that were participating in such a activity since he was out of the goodness of his heart was trying to help.
My father, Will Presnell, was a very patient man and many people say that I am much like my father in that I show a great deal of patience when times are difficult.
A very trying period of time for my mother particularly was when I was about two and a half years old.
I fell off the front porch and broke my leg in the upper portion of the thigh portion and was taken to the hospital and the leg was put in a cast.
The leg grew back
But it was not straight.

And the doctor gave my mother and father the choice of either letting it stay like that or breaking it over, hoping that the break would be in the right place and that the leg would be OK. My mother primarily made the choice of re-breaking the leg and hoping that it would break right and could be reset.
It worked out fine, and I had never had any problems with it.
The problem with the leg was the fact that the fracture was so high close to my hip that both legs should have been suspended with a pulley as I lay flat on my back.
And the doctor only suspended one leg.
And as a result, when I twisted and turned, that got the fracture grew back and was not in properly positioned.
So I have my mother primarily to thank for the fact that I did not have to grow up as a cripple.
In addition to my grandfather's extensive farming operations through sharecroppers,
My father had his own tracts of land and some farming was done primarily on the haves.
And so my father spent much of the time after things settled down and were not so busy in the store, out overseeing the farming operations.
while I stayed in the store and ran the store.
It would have been impossible in my early days to do that because the store was very active.
It had over seven employees and sold everything that you could imagine that was needed to run a household and to run a farm.
As I became a teenager, all the sharecroppers virtually were gone, had moved to town.
and the land was converted primarily to cattle operations.
There was some farming, but it was done with tractors.
At the tender age of six, when I entered public schools, there was a school just up the road.
At that time, it taught all 11 grades.
The high school did not have a 12th grade as it does today.
It was a rural school called Tabor High School.
It was a wonderful experience with some great teachers.
Although it was small and the teaching staff was only about seven or eight teachers, they were all very confident and did an excellent job of giving the children the background that they needed.
I recall about the second grade, a cyclone or tornado
hit the school building and virtually knocked it off of its props.
It was up in the air on stilts almost with brick columns.
I remember that we could walk under the school building, most of it, and so it was not destroyed but made inoperable by knocking it off its props, so to speak.
That led to building another school building and, in the process, added an auditorium and gymnasium.
And for the first time, we were able to participate in sports, primarily volleyball and basketball, indoors.
Up to that time, basketball was played on the outside on gravel courts and could really skin up your knees.

I was a little young at that time and was fortunate enough to do most of my basketball playing after the new gymnasium was completed and enjoyed participating in that sport, although I was usually playing with much older boys and bigger boys and got to participate very little in this varsity sport.
I got to ride the bench a lot, but played very little.
When the tornado hit, it was very unexpected.
We did not have the warning facilities that are available today.
And it was very fortunate that no one was hurt.
After all, there were over 100 children in the school building, and there was one long porch
that fell to the ground.
But as I say, no one was hurt, and all except the small ones.
And I was in that category.
Went to the ditches and laid down in the ditches until it had passed.
It's one of those events that many adults today still remember where they were when the tornado hit the school.
Within a few years,
Tabor High School began to move some of its grades to Bryan High School.
For example, the high school was run away with first and integrated with Bryan, leaving the other nine grades in the school at Tabor.
The year I was in the sixth grade,
The upper grades from the fifth on were abolished, so I entered Lamar Junior High School in Bryan on the seventh grade level.
This was a good experience, although most of the families and kids in my class were not happy with it because they really wanted to stay in a small rural school.
Frankly, it was not a challenge.
It was probably too easy to pass.
And it was time that we needed the challenge of a school system such as Bryan had to offer.
Moving to the Bryan schools also brought about a different mix of students
as opposed to the ones that attended the Tabor school.
The Tabor school was sprinkled pretty heavily with first generation Italians that lived in the area between Tabor and Bryan and were still farming the land.
I recall quite vividly that many of these kids could not start the school until about a month after
began in September because of the fact that they had to pick cotton during the month of September and they would finally be able to come to school for the first time around the first of October.
So things were kind of held back waiting for these kids to get in school and allow them an opportunity to catch up.
But this was just the times we lived in where kids were necessary
labor to pick the cotton that was grazed on their farms.
For a while, I lost track of some of these kids that I went to school with, but began to run into them again when I engaged in my first political campaign in 1968.
Most of them had stayed in Bryan.
Many of them were running convenience stores
and were small entrepreneurs, and they were in a position to be a great help, and they were certainly good friends that I'll always remember.
There were many influences on my life.
One was the 4-H Club that I joined when I was just nine years of age, and I was able to travel to Dallas and to Houston to those livestock shows
and show some of my livestock over the years that I was raising.
This was a good experience and one that I'll always treasure.
The reason it was such a good experience was because of the great leadership that Wallace Kimbrough, who was the county agent for most of those years, furnished the program.

I'll always remember Mr. Kimbrough and we hope that his memory will stay alive for years to come through a scholarship program that my brother and I and several others started for him in his name at Texas A&M University.
The scholarship is awarded each year at the annual awards program of the Brazos County 4-H
club and provided to the student that demonstrates scholarship, leadership, and judging ability.
One of the programs that Mr. Kimbrough started that had an impact on the lives of many of us was the livestock judging programs.
I recall
I placed first in a dairy judging contest at the Houston Flat Stock Show and Livestock Show one year and won a dairy heifer.
That probably increased my interest in the dairy industry as a result of winning that heifer and having to go back and show it at the Livestock Show the next year.
As a youngster, I was extremely shy, but I had a strong compulsion to join the Methodist Church and accept Jesus Christ as my personal Savior at an early age.
However, because of my shyness, I resisted a number of times when the invitation was offered.
Finally, we had an elderly pastor by the name of Reverend Day
who took me fishing one afternoon and it helped overcome some of my timidity and so the next Sunday when the invitation was offered I went forward and joined the church.
For some reason it became easier after I had had an opportunity to go fishing with Reverend Day.
In high school I
joined the Future Farmers of America and continued my interest in agriculture, but never left the 4-H club.

There was some school of thought that a person should devote all of his time to one or the other, and in many areas this was emphasized and encouraged, but I was never encouraged to leave the 4-H club and devote all of my time to Future Farmers of America.
In hindsight, I think this was a good thing because each one of them offered different opportunities during my high school days.
The Future Farmers of America offered more opportunity for leadership training, which I found very helpful for the rest of my life, particularly during the years I served in the legislature.
Upon entering high school, I
participated in a calf scramble as a member of the Future Farmers of America and went on the next year to win Grand Champion.
I did not get much in the way of remuneration for my award, but it was a lot of fun.
In fact, I recall the calf brought 36 cents a pound
which was not much money now and was certainly not much money even then for a Grand Champion keg.
As a 4-H'er in 1949, I entered the dairy judging contest in Houston, as I mentioned earlier, and won a dairy heifer fair as a result of winning
being number one in the judging contest.
This was quite an accomplishment at the time because there were several hundred 4-H'ers that were entered in the judging contest.
Later on, our team won state judging in, in dairy judging in 1949, and we had an opportunity to go to the national contest in Memphis, Tennessee.
And this was probably my first trip outside of the state of Texas.
And it was very enjoyable.
We traveled with the state winning FFA team that was out of Burleson, Texas.
And I still see occasionally one of those judging team members who is a member of the faculty in the University of Mississippi.
That same year, I entered Texas A&M as a freshman student and, of course, entered the Corps of Cadets.
The freshmen at that time were stationed at what is now known as the Riverside Campus of Texas A&M University on Highway 21 just west of Bryan.
It was an old Air Force base that had been abandoned
and turned over to Texas A&M.
We lived in barracks, about 20 to each barrack, and it was not the best of conditions for studying and getting rest.
But we had a lot of fun, and I managed to make my grades, although many of the fellows that I was in the same barracks with flunked out after one semester, or at least the second semester.
At the end of that freshman year, it was necessary to select the branch of service that we wanted to continue our military experience with.
I selected the US Air Force and continued my training, ROTC training, in the Air Force ROTC.
At the end of the first semester,
I had decided to move home because of the fact that I had a rather large project of egg production.
This was putting me through school but was certainly a burden to my mother who was having to take care of them while I was living out at the O'Brien Air Force Base.

or they called it then the annex, I felt like I could be of some service by being at home and traveling back and forth and at least marketing the eggs and from time to time helping with tending to my laying hens.
It is amazing now to look back how profitable the egg production operation was.
by today's standards, very small, but at that time was rather large.
In fact, there was only one or two operations in the county that were larger than mine.
I look back at the records that I kept at that time were at the peak of the laying season.
I was netting as much as a dollar per chicken

per month this would be unbelievable by today's standards in 1950 we all moved to the main campus since only freshmen were at the annex and that same year the annex was closed we were the last class to be at the annex and incidentally the annex was placed there because of the hazing problems
that existed on the campus.
And the thought was that if they could separate the freshmen out for four years, that there would be little or no hazing at Texas A&M in the Corps of Cadets.
Frankly, it didn't work that way.
There still was hazing.
But it probably helped to change the attitudes of some of the cadets through the separation that we experienced.
I decided early on to major in dairy science since I had been involved with my dairy project, and my father by then had entered the dairy business with his brother, Charlie Preston.
The dairy was located close to or on the land that I now own.
Now, one of the people that had a great influence on my life was the vocational agriculture teacher and the sponsor of Future Farmers of America in Brown for many years, Mr. J.C. Dooley.
I got much of my leadership training through the Future Farmer program.
I served as secretary and president of the local chapter.
Had a long time experience with Mr. Dooley when I later joined the Young Farmers Association as a charter member and as its charter president here in Bryan.
It was no surprise to anyone, I'm sure, that I selected the field of agriculture and I decided on a degree plan at Texas A&M.
However, as a senior in Bryan High School, I really became interested in two other fields.
First, I enjoyed designing house plans, and so architecture was a strong consideration for a long time.
I also considered the School of Veterinary Medicine.
But in both cases, the programs were more than four years, and as a result,
Maybe just due to laziness, I decided I wanted a four-year program and chose not to select either one of those programs.
I would be remiss not to mention some of my boyhood acquaintances during the time that I was growing up at Tabor, where I had lived all of my life.
mentioned earlier, we lived close to the school where there was a home called the teacherage that was provided the school principal.
He had two sons who were close to my age.
One was in my grade, and we played together.
The one my age is now a minister of education.
at the First Baptist Church in Harlingen, Texas, and we have maintained some communication over the years.
Another neighbor just down the road on the other side of my home was a boy named Elvin Barnes, and we were together almost constantly.
Elvin's father
was a blacksmith and I guess that may have contributed to my interest in tinkering.
We were always up to something.
I recall one time we took a starter motor off of an old truck that my father owned and mounted it on a wagon and were going to run the starter motor with a battery.
So it would essentially have been a battery-powered car.

This possibly is where my first tinkering with things started, and I have been accused by a former chancellor of the Texas University System of enjoying tinkering with legislation, or as he referred to it, being the fiddler in the band.
I'm sure there are many other traits that I picked up in those early boyhood, high school, college days that contributed to my adulthood.
They're sometimes very difficult to identify all of them.
But I'm sure that my opportunity to conduct meetings and provide some leadership helped
when I entered the legislature and was given leadership responsibilities there.
I know that it made a difference in my confidence level to conduct meetings and to arrive at consensus views with my colleagues in the legislature and to get things done that had to be done.
All of these
Experiences and training helped overcome the shy person that I was, but I'm not sure that I totally overcame my shyness except for the short period of time that I had to run for office in 1968.
and I probably reverted back to some of it even after that event took place.
One of the opportunities that I was provided during my boyhood days was a chance to read quite a bit in the summer months.
At that time, the county provided a bookmobile that went around the
to the rural counties, rural communities, and provided a library, moving library.
And so one day each week, the bookmobile would park in front of our store, which was next door to our home.
And I had the opportunity to check out a book.
turn in the ones that I had previously checked out, and read the book before the bookmobile returned the next week.
If it had not been for the bookmobile, I probably would have not read as much as I did during those summer months.
I'm sure all of that reading was helpful to me in my schoolwork and giving me more ability to read.
Another educational opportunity that was afforded was through the phonics program that was just being developed when I was a second grader.
And one of the originators of the phonics program came to our school from College Station and taught phonics to us.
I will always believe that had a great deal to do with my ability to sound out almost any word and to spell virtually any word.
Sometimes it doesn't quite work out phonetically, but most of the time it does.
And I am a strong believer that phonics contributed a great deal to my educational progress.
Throughout those boyhood days, it seemed that opportunities were always presenting themselves just at the right time.
And I'll always be grateful and feel quite fortunate that things worked out as they did.
It was good to live in a rural community
to have a rural background and to experience those things that only someone raised in a rural area can experience.
At the same time, I got a good education through the Bryan system, which was known as one of the best in the state at the time.
And so many things that happened that people that came my way that I will always be grateful
This is chapter two, which will deal with my ancestry.
I do not wish to reiterate a lot of work that has been done on the genealogy of the two branches of the family of my mother and father, but I would like to give some
information that may not show up on any of the genealogy work that has been done.
Both my mother and father were from pioneer families that helped settle Brazos County, and I think that some of this is worth mentioning because it gave them very strong ties
to this area and relationship with many people both through family, kinship, and friends that influenced my life a great deal.
On my mother's side of the family, her grandmother was of a Kurd family that settled in the Kurd community
on a grant that had been provided by Stephen F. Austin.

They probably would have stayed there for generations to come, but started feuding with the Millicans on the southern end of the county, and as a result, one of the Kurd boys shot one of the Millican boys, and their land at Curtin had to be sold
to defend the Kurd boy and keep him out of prison.
It seems very strange and ironic and I don't know the explanation for it, but years later the two families made up and the Kurd family moved to Milliken and were sponsored by the Milliken family.
This moved my grandmother closer to where
My grandfather was being raised by the Clay family in Clay Station, just on the other side of the Brazos River.
Little is known about my grandfather on my mother's side, except that he was raised by the Clay family and was given to the family, provided to the family, maybe is a better word,
in St. Louis, Missouri.
The Clay family was very good to him, and this is indicated by the fact that he stayed with the family until he was 24.
He could have left under the arrangement that they had at the age of 21.
Some of the more pleasant experiences that my mother remembered
was having been raised as a child where the Texas World Speedway is now established.
My mother had two brothers and four sisters.
The two brothers were Lewis Marquette, was a carpenter in Houston, and lost a hand in an accidental
gun discharge while he was home on leave during World War I.
Uncle Lewis had two boys that still live in Houston.
The other brother was Seth, known as Bud Marquardt.
Uncle Bud was a carpenter that lived in the either Bryan College Station or Navistota during his lifetime.
Uncle Bud is the only one that's still alive at the time I am recording this.
The oldest sister was Lena Allen, whose husband was Eddie Allen, a landowner of some renown in the Peach Creek community.
Uncle Eddie was known to buy
land that joined him and that he accumulated a great deal of property over the years.

Aunt Lena and Uncle Ebby had ten children and Uncle Ebby's ambition was to leave each one of them a thousand acres and a hundred head of cattle and he accomplished this by accumulating ten thousand acres of land and a thousand head of cattle in the Beech Creek community just south of College Station.
Some of those children still live in the Beach Creek and College Station community.
Others have since moved away.
Another large family was mother's sister, Liddy Arnold, who was married to Henry Arnold.
Uncle Henry worked for Texas A&M, his adult life in the power plant, the home
that they lived in that I recall other than the time they lived in Wilburn is where the Central Park and College Station is located.
The pavilion has a plaque recognizing the family's residence there in the park where the pavilion is.
Two of Mother's sisters moved to the Baytown area
When they married, or shortly after they married, Addie Baker married Uncle Raleigh Baker, and they had six children.
They stayed in Milliken for a while, but he moved to Baytown.
The family moved to Baytown when one of the older boys was six years of age, and he worked for Humble Oil and Refining Company for the rest of his life.
My family was probably closer to the Baker family than any of the others.
We paired off quite well in age and the fact that there was one about the same age in each family and of the same sex.
The Baker that was my age was Charles Baker, who was
now an orthopedic surgeon in Houston, Texas.
The oldest son of the Baker family was R.W.
Baker, who was quite instrumental in the fact that he was involved in political endeavors much of his life and got me interested in an indirect way in politics.
In addition to that, he came to Bryan one day and wanted to start a local bank.
And we decided on a location in College Station.
It became known as Commerce National Bank and is now known as Compass Bank.
And this has been quite an experience in developing the bank.
We ended up buying out the Baker family
several years after the bank was started.
R.W.
's interest in politics was right after the war, came back and ran for state representative in Houston.
He was defeated in that first race, but came back to be elected later and served in the House for several sessions before he, several terms before he was elected as the
lone state senator for Harris County.
After serving only about one term in the state senate, he decided to run for lieutenant governor.
He entered a race and would have won the race probably had there been a decent turnout that day in Houston, Texas.
The turnout was very low and, as a result, was defeated by a very, very small margin by the person who later became governor, Preston Smith.
R.W.
would probably have been the first Aggie governor had it not been for that slim margin of defeat back in about 1972.
I'm sorry, 62, 62.
My involvement in that race I will discuss later.
Mother's youngest sister I knew as Aunt Bitt.
Her last name was Taylor.
She was married to Hoyt Taylor, and they lived in Pelley, Texas, which is now a part of Baytown.
She had two boys and one girl, Hoyt Jr., Jimmy, and June Marie.
The two boys had lived their lives in Bryan College Station in June Marie.
He is married and lives in Austin, Texas.
Turning to my father's side of the family, a little bit more is known because of his grandfather's keeping of records that we still have to this day.
Those old ledgers that we have in our possession date back to the early 1850s and run through 1882.
His name was R. H. Hudspeth, and he, along with his brother T. H. Hudspeth, ran a general store in Wheelock, Texas in about...
the early 1860s, he closed the store in Wheelock and joined the Confederate Army as a captain in the Hoods Brigade.
And when he returned, he never opened the store, but moved in with his daughter, Mary, who was my grandmother.
My father spent much time with his grandfather, R.H. Hudspeth, and he tells me that he was reluctant to talk about the Civil War.
He was a scout and apparently had many experiences that he would just rather forget.
I found this in one of the old ledgers
He wrote in 1869, after his service in the Hood Brigade, he wrote, quote, many men of many minds, many men of many kinds, and a good many of no minds at all.
I'm not sure what this tells us about the man, but he apparently...
able to overcome those experiences after a while and go on with his life.

He purchased a rather large tract of land from a Colonel Giddings, or through Colonel Giddings, probably Giddings, Texas is named for, and began farming and ranching, primarily ranching in the Terrier area.
I have 100 acres of that land today.
At the time, he purchased about 2,000 acres from all indications of the records that I have.
As I say, he kept extensive records, records such things as school attendance of the kids, bad weather days, the sickness of his employees.
Interestingly enough, they seemed like the kids started to school at a very odd time of the year.
But he kept a record of all these kinds of happenings.
He raised a lot of sheep, hogs, and cattle.
He had a lot of records of him paying sheep herders.
They made $15 a month working full time as sheep herders.
In 1871, he paid $15.37 in ad valorem taxes.
This was for the 1,537 acres that he owned in the area where my farm is today.
He had five horses, 50 cows, 520 sheep, 25 hogs, one wagon, one bucky, and one bull.
At the same time, the balance of it, there was some land that came up the total of 2,000 acres in the name of
Mrs. M. M. Hudspeth.
I'm not sure who M. M. Hudspeth is.
She had 400 acres.
And then Mrs. Mary Hudspeth had 212 acres.
Mary Hudspeth was my grandmother.
M. M. Hudspeth was probably another daughter that we know as the Hudspeth Prairie.
